page.title: 19The Dunmow Flitch (History)
page.content: The Dunmow Flitch is a very old custom. It probably started when Little Dunmow Priory gave a prize of bacon to people who were willing to go through a religious ceremony of marriage. There were awards of bacon in the 16th Century, but in 1536 Henry closed the monastries down and the custom died. It was revived by the local lord of the manor in 1701, but by 1751 the custom died again. A Victorian author W Harrison Ainsworth, wrote a novel called the Flitch of Bacon, and in 1855 he revived the trials as a publicity stunt, using the old Town Hall in Dunmow. The custom has continued ever since, with gaps for the two World Wars, and has settled into a pattern of once every four years, the last time being 1984.
